name: Nichole
comment info:
I noticed that for some foods, people thought it was healthy, but nutritionists thought it was unhealthy. For other foods, it was the other way around. For example, only 30% of nutritionists think frozen yogurt is healthy, but 65% of all Americans think it is healthy. But, 90% of nutritionists think quinoa is healthy, but only 55% of all Americans think it is healthy. So, in this graph, the population and nutritionists have opposing opinions. 

I wonder why people have such different opinions than the nutritionists. Maybe because Americans grew up learning what was healthy and what wasn't, and they didn't really try to take a closer look at these foods. Nutritionists spend their time studying food to see what is healthy, so they have more experience about what is healthy. 

You can infer from this graph that some of the foods Americans think are healthy aren't actually very healthy. Or, we think something is unhealthy when it is healthy. This graph goes beyond food because it shows that what we learn isn't always the truth.

I wonder why Americans don't realize how quinoa and sushi are healthy because, using sushi as my example again, it's just seaweed, rice, fish, and maybe a vegetable (like avocado). name: Bart
comment info:
I see scatterplot with nutritionists' opinion on Y and Americans' opinion on X axis. 45 degree line shows possible situation when both groups will be consistent with the their opinions. And it is not the case as the line does not fit well. 

Let's divide the chart into four quadrants on 50% / 50% point. There are four clusters here.
I - less than 50% of both groups find particular food healthy (cookies, soda)
II- more than 50% of both groups find particular food healthy (cheese, orange).
III - food found more healthy by Americans than nutritionists (granola, bars).
IV - food found more healthy by nutritionists than Americans (popcorn, wine, sushi).

Healthiness of the product is not a binary thing - products are well placed across the reference line, some of them are easier to define as healthy, some cause troubles  - cheese, pork chops. So we should use our intuition and not follow recommendations blindely

Products above the line are said to be more healty by nutritionists, below - more healty by americans. 

I am wondering - Why is there strong disagreement between Americans and nutritionists and how it can be changed?

The story behind the graph - the both groups vote similar o certain degree, there are types of food that are not recommended by nutritionists but Americans think otherwise. On the other hand there is food with potential that Americans are not fully aware about. And we want to let them think again before eating another granola bar. Sushi may be better :)

However, some foods that Americans think are unhealthy are actually deemed as healthy by nutritionists and vice versa. This implies that what nutritionists are saying is not getting through to most Americans and that we have many misconceptions about the healthiness of different foods.

I wonder whether the information from this graph has even greater impacts that we do not see directly in the visual. For example, perhaps the graph shows how media has influenced our views on foods and given us the wrong ideas about what seems healthy to us and what is actually healthy according to nutritionists. If we were to pay more attention to the facts, we would be able to make healthier choices about what we eat. I also wonder if there is a reason for these specific foods to be shown on the graph. Are these the most popular foods bought by consumers in America, or perhaps something else entirely?

In the graph, there is a linear regression, showing that most foods are agreed on to an extent to be seen as healthy or unhealthy to both Americans and nutritionists. However, the foods that are not on top of this linear regression can be interpreted as misconceptions of the foods' healthiness. The deeper story to this graph may be that we have found a better way for people to diet and become healthier because when people may have thought they were eating healthily, they actually weren't

name: tessej
comment info:
I notice that, in general, most of the foods included in this graph fall close to the y = x line, implying that most of Americans' perceptions of what foods are healthy or not coincide with the opinions of nutritionists. I also notice that there are certain clusters that fall both below and above the y = x line. Below, there is a cluster including granola and frozen yogurt while a cluster above includes tofu and quinoa. The cluster of foods below the y = x line includes foods that Americans deem to be more healthy than nutritionists while the cluster above includes foods that nutritionists say are healthier than what Americans believe them to be.

I wonder why there is disagreement among the foods found in the clusters both above and below the y = x line. Why are there different perceptions of the health of these foods when there seems to be agreement among many of the others? One idea I had was that items such as frozen yogurt are heavily marketed as being a healthy alternative or choice which could lead the general public to view them as healthier than they actually are. Meanwhile, foods like quinoa are not marketed as often which may lead Americans to be unaware of their true nutritional merit.

The story this graph is telling is that, in general, Americans as a whole tend to agree with nutritionists when deeming foods healthy or not, yet there are certain groups of food in which nutritionists and Americans do not agree upon which could be a result of marketing.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to What’s Going On in This Graph?.   Do you think you eat healthy foods?  Are you eating healthy?  Maybe these are not easy questions to answer.  Take a hard look at the graph.
What do you NOTICE?  What this may imply?
What do you WONDER?  Where could you find the answers to what you wonder?
What’s the STORY this graph tells?  Use what you notice.  What can you infer that is beyond what this graph shows directly?
The questions are intended to build on one another, so try to answer them in order. Start with “I notice” and then “I wonder,” and end with “The story this graph is telling is ….”
And, your personal perspective may relate the graph not only to its statistics, but also science, history, literature, or somewhere else.
Then, read what other students have to say.  Possibly, what they notice and wonder will lead you to other insights about the graph.  Press "reply" to respond to other comments.
 We look forward to reading your discoveries.

name: ElRudi
comment info:
I notice many foods are on the y=x line, meaning public and nutritionists as a whole have similar views on healtiness of a food. I also notice there is a distinct group of foods (frozen yogurt, granola, coconut oil) that has probably been successfully marketed to the public as healty, even though in reality, it isn't.

Only considering the y-component for now, I wonder why there are so many foods on which there is no consensus among nutritionists. A relatively large percentage of foods is considered healty by between 20% and 80% - meaning that you wouldn't find agreement on them among 5 nutritionists.

I wonder if the disagreement among nutritionists stems from the vagueness of 'healty', the fact that some unhealty aspects of a food are subjectively weighed against the healty ones, and that only a yes/no verdict can be given.

I'm not sure what this graph is telling. At first glance I thought it was 'public not that misinformed about healtiness of foods', or 'eat more from top right group, eat less from bottom left group', but it's also showing that opinions vary wildly when given only a binary option (healty / not healty) and that clear-cut advice can only be given for very few foods.
